content.description: This is a thirty-foot-long, 80-degree overhung offwidth problem.  Though the length, overhang, and offwidth suggest a much harder problem, some large holds inside the crack make the climbing considerably easier.  This is a good, moderate introduction to offwidth roof cracks.  The rock texture is abrasive, so knee protection is recommended for the leg jams.
content.location: When walking up the trail from the Panorama Point parking lot,  the trail passes a bouldering traverse on the south side of the Panorama Rock area. Just north of the trail is a small hole.  Sit start the climb on good edges just east of this hole,  climb into the hole,  then grovel upside-down for 30 feet or so until you emerge on a ledge on the other side of the rock.

content.description: This dynamic traverse has lots of variations. The classic being the sds at the arete and traversing left, swimming up the large flake and out the small chimney. Variations include adding the east face, which bumps it up a grade.
content.location: Drive up Flagstaff Rd., and park at the first parking area (Panorama Point). Cross the road, follow the obvious trail past the bathrooms, and 100m later you're there.

content.description:
This is an old aid line that is quite fun and a little to a lot heady to boulder, a bit highball to a midway drop or very highball to the top. It starts on the large wall on the north side of Pumpkin Rock. After a few moves, it moves left into pin scars and then goes directly up. It is also listed as

North Overhang Left

, 5.12, for the full line. Drop from the midway crack, around 20 feet, or finish up the X rated topout. It is best to rehearse the moves on TR if the latter.
Start low in the notch on the face and then work up and right and fInish on the ramp.
content.location: This is on a smaller face 20 feet left of the Northwest Face. Start low. To get down, walk straight towards to the trail and walk around the boulder.

content.description: This is one of two obvious lines on the North Side. Follow a rail and zig-zagging crack system up to a notch.
content.protection: 2 eyebolts, you need double slings to get over the lip.
content.location: Scramble up easy 5th terrain on the south side to set up a TR. It is fun rap to the base.

content.description:
This is an old aid practice line that follows heavily pin-scarred cracks up to join with

North Overhang Right

at the notch. I haven't climbed it, the grade is a guess.
content.protection: 2 eyebolts, you need double slings to get over the lip.
content.location: Scramble up easy 5th terrain on the south side to set up TR. It is a fun rap to the base.

content.description: Directly below an old eyebolt for a toprope, the route follows an almost direct line on very steep to vertical rock. Some larger holds help, but it is something of an *enduro* type problem. This is a fun, get-in-shape route. There are several different lines that account for the range on difficulty.
content.location: The top of the rock can be accessed easily on the SW corner by some 3rd class scrambling. The eyebolt is the obvious anchor for a toprope.
